Inside the House leadership scramble.

            By 
Jake Sherman

09/29/15 10:58 AM EDT
House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy drew his most stark contrast with John Boehner Tuesday morning, saying there's a generational difference between himself and the speaker, and that he wants to bring Washington closer to the American people.
First, Boehner told McCarthy to "be careful, I'm standing right here." McCarthy (R-Calif.) said he'd be different than Boehner (R-Ohio) because he "won't be as tan." McCarthy called him a "good and decent man," and ticked off some of Boehner's accomplishments — including winning two majorities — but then said "everybody is different."
"I know what's going on across the country, and I'm concerned about what we hear," McCarthy said in the Capitol. "A lot of people in Washington are concerned about power and institutions. I'm concerned about making a difference in everybody's life. We want to make sure that we're closer to the people. That they feel this is their government, they're in charge and we serve them. Now that's not easy, and that won't change overnight. But that's our mission."
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
description: "We want to make sure that we're closer to the people. That they feel this is their government, they're in charge and we serve them."
title: McCarthy draws generational contrast with Boehner
